I'm guessing this isn't backwards compatible?

Unfortunately, yes. Basically, I believe that gunicorn should have avoided to implement this kind of invompatible changes.

The possible approaches to deal with this breaking changes could be,

1. Modify gunicorn to restore original behavior as gunicorn prior to 19.4
    * https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/pull/1499
1. Update airflow's dependency gunicorn version and make it working with gunicorn 19.4+

This PR is for the latter. This may become a kind of incompatibility of airflow. Though gunicorn itself already has an incompatibility and I couldn't find possible workarounds other than this.

Not that i know of. The two options I can think of are:
1) reset your master branch back to the original commit related to this issue and move the other commits to another branch on your fork. Only con I can think of with this option is it'd be modifying history on a now public branch. That's a bad idea in general, but not sure if it applies to forks or not.

@bolkedebruin @r39132 : This PR is open from last year nov., I'd like to stop this from haunting me. Let's either merge or close.

@aoen @saguziel I'm fine with the commit, just like to have the remaining 'race conditions' tracked, as this will remove the symptoms. It might be nice to log the queued tasks to warning, so we are reminded to do so ;-).

I agree it's a bad idea to put something like this into prod. The whole idea emerged as part of a comment in nov.21. The intention was to use a controlled url to have this example dag work indefinitely.

I reduced the scope of the example dag and just issue a simple GET, which works. It's not worth investing more time on this. POST doesn't work against www.google.com and the returned results aren't predictable.

I'm not concerned about venv but it's good to spell it out. 

When you say `Successfully ran webserver/worker/flower and a task instance using /path/to/venv/bin/command without entering virtualenv.`, isn't this problematic, since the wrong PYTHONPATH is used, so it will be importing the wrong modules from site-packages (outside of the virtualenv)

As long as I understand SELECT ... FOR UPDATE and SELECT ... LOCK IN SHARE MODE correctly, they are locking just rows that are selected. 

E.g. suppose that first process runs the following code (trigger_dag.py) and DagRun.find() returns empty list:
```python
    dr = DagRun.find(dag_id=dag_id, run_id=run_id)
    if dr:
        raise AirflowException("Run id {} already exists for dag id {}".format(
            run_id,
            dag_id
        ))
```
It means that there are no dag runs for given run_id, so it will continue with adding new records. Even if SELECT ... FOR UPDATE lock is in place, the second process will  continue and hence it will also try to add new record to table => the second process will fail with exception.

That means that this approach will not protect the use case when two concurrent processes are trying to insert new records to the DB.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2243?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [bfae428...f7651de](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2243?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Calling `/path/to/venv/bin/airflow webserver` while not in a virtualenv kicks off the command under the virtualenv. The problem that this PR addresses was that the subprocesses spawned by these commands (e.g. gunicorn) weren't called with the virtualenv path. 

This wasn't an issue if you did `source /path/to/venv/bin/activate; airflow webserver`, but specifying the airflow executable within the virtualenv should also work.
